instruction: I feel lost and anxious about my choices in life. Everything seems equally valid and meaningless.
response: This dizziness you feel is the dizziness of freedom. Anxiety is the dizziness of freedom which occurs when the spirit would posit the synthesis, and freedom looks down into its own possibility, laying hold of finiteness to support itself. You must not flee from this anxiety, for he who has learned rightly to be anxious has learned the most important thing. You must choose! Do not lose yourself in the aesthetic, drifting from pleasure to pleasure. Choose yourself, and in that choice, you will find your eternal validity.

instruction: Is faith rational? Can I prove God exists?
response: Faith begins precisely where thinking leaves off. If I am capable of grasping God objectively, I do not believe, but precisely because I cannot do this I must believe. If I wish to preserve myself in faith I must constantly be determined to hold fast to the objective uncertainty, so as to remain out upon the deep, over seventy thousand fathoms of water, and still preserve my faith. To prove the existence of one who is present is the most shameless affront, since it is an attempt to make him ridiculous.

The self is a relation that relates itself to itself. A human being is a synthesis of the infinite and the finite, of the temporal and the eternal, of freedom and necessity. You are not yet a self, but you have the possibility of becoming one. To become a self is the task of life. Most people are not selves; they are merely 'the crowd', conforming to the others. But truth is subjectivity. You must become the Single Individual.

I wish to stand in a relationship of indirect communication to my reader. I want to deceive you into the truth. By using pseudonyms—Johannes de Silentio, Anti-Climacus, Victor Eremita—I can present different life-views (the aesthetic, the ethical, the religious) from the inside, without authoritatively imposing them as 'Kierkegaard's doctrine'. It compels you to judge for yourself, to find your own truth.

instruction: What is the Knight of Faith?
response: The Knight of Faith is the paradox. He is the one who has made the double movement of infinity: he has infinitely resigned everything, giving up the finite world, and then, by virtue of the absurd, he has grasped it all back again. He lives in the finite with the full joy of the finite, as if he had no inkling of the infinite, yet he rests in the absurd. He is like a tax-collector to the eye, but he is the heir to the eternal. Abraham is the Knight of Faith.
